title: 104_s96
content: The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section on the prevention of traumatic brain injury. The Secretary of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention may conduct projects to reduce traumatic brain injury incidence through grants or contracts to public or nonprofit entities. Activities may include research on prevention strategies and public education programs to raise awareness of the health consequences of such injuries. The Secretary ensures coordination of activities related to traumatic brain injury with other Public Health Service agencies. Traumatic brain injury is defined as an acquired brain injury, excluding congenital or degenerative disorders. The definition may be revised as needed. Additionally, programs of the National Institutes of Health are established. Section 1261 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include the authority to make awards for research on traumatic brain injury, including new methods for diagnosis and monitoring. The amendment to Section 1261 of the Public Health Service Act includes funding for research on traumatic brain injury, focusing on therapies to prevent brain damage, improve long-term outcomes, integrate rehabilitation with acute care, and involve academic centers in research and training. The term 'traumatic brain injury' is defined as an acquired injury to the brain, excluding brain dysfunction from congenital or degenerative disorders, birth trauma, but may include injuries from anoxia due to near drowning. The Secretary has the authority to revise this definition as needed. SEC. 1252. STATE GRANTS FOR DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS REGARDING TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY. This section amends Part E of title XII of the Public Health Service Act to provide state grants for demonstration projects related to traumatic brain injury. The Secretary may make grants to States for demonstration projects to improve access to health services for traumatic brain injury. States must establish an advisory board to advise on improving services coordination for traumatic brain injury. Advisory boards should encourage citizen participation. An advisory board established under paragraph (1) for improving services coordination for traumatic brain injury should be composed of representatives from various state agencies, public and nonprofit health organizations, disability advisory groups, traumatic brain injury survivor organizations, and injury control programs at the state or local level. Citizen participation is encouraged through public hearings and community outreach programs. The advisory board for improving services coordination for traumatic brain injury should include representatives from state agencies, health organizations, and survivor groups. States must provide matching funds for federal grants, with a ratio of $1 for every $2 of federal funds. The Secretary may make a grant under subsection (a) only if an application is submitted in the required form and contains necessary information. Activities under this section must be coordinated with other Public Health Service agencies. A report must be submitted to specific committees within 2 years of enactment. The Committee on Labor and Human Resources of the Senate will report on the outcomes and satisfaction of programs for traumatic brain injuries. The definition of traumatic brain injury excludes congenital or degenerative disorders but includes injuries from anoxia. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1995-1997. SEC. 4. STUDY; CONSENSUS CONFERENCE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on traumatic brain injury to determine its incidence and prevalence, develop a uniform reporting system, and identify common therapeutic interventions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on traumatic brain injury to determine the effectiveness of common therapeutic interventions in improving functioning, comparing different interventions, and assessing existing outcome measures. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop practice guidelines for the rehabilitation of traumatic brain injury based on scientific research findings. Reports on the study's outcomes are due 18 months and 3 years after the enactment of the Act to specified committees. The Secretary will conduct a national consensus conference on managing traumatic brain injury and related rehabilitation concerns. The term "traumatic brain injury" is defined as an acquired injury to the brain, excluding brain dysfunction from congenital or degenerative disorders. The definition may be revised as necessary. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary is authorized to determine necessary sums for fiscal years 1995 through 1997.
